title: Why Do We Need Language Technology?

author: Lori Thicke, Lexcelera
recorded by: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)

segmentation: Great, thank you very much.
I'm here today to talk about the huge and pressing need for language technology which is related to the huge in pressing need for more access to information.
Because I am.
Here, representing two different organizations, I'm going to tell you about both of them.

The first is like Celerra, which is my translation company I founded in 1986 in Paris and I'm very proud that we were the first localization company to be ISO 9001 certified in France, and that's important in RMT work which I'm going to talk about were known for quality, empty, and in fact I think that's the only empty we should really be talking about.
None of our customers have come to us for bad quality empty.
The old one, quality empty and that's that's one of the things one of the takeaways today.
I hope that I can leave with you is the idea of how can we improve quality empty empty?

We are also one of the only players in the market who are working with both roles based in SMT, and I think that's a very, very important distinction to make when you're talking about quality, and T is not Israel space.
Better is SMT better.
What's better for what use?

So I think that that we have to stop talking about one or the other and the hybrid is is for example the system hybrid which we use does bring the two together, but there are different use cases for SMT and for rules based.

Just quickly, for example, we're going to talk about form content that's really good with SMT unstructured Wild West kind of content, but where you need to have the terminology very strictly useful, spaced OK, and I also represent translators Without Borders I.
One of many of, you know, organization we're bringing together the whole industry.
I see at least one sponsor down the grasmick from new software.
We were founded in Paris in 1990.
Three were both the French and US charity.
What translators Without Borders does is provide pro bono support to humanitarian organizations.
Since May 2011, we have donated and this is the exact number as of yesterday.
It's higher today, 3 million, 978 thousand 450 words to 73.
17 nonprofit organizations, such as Doctors Without Borders, Ox Fam Handicap International African Medical Relief, etc.
So we support humanitarian work around the world and we also are working for access to knowledge.
This is my welcome to my world slide this is.
But the reality is, for localization companies today we have an extremely fragmented market.
Is there she was talking about fragmented tools.
We have fragmented suppliers.
No one has a big share of the market is very, very fragmented market in terms of thousands and thousands of LSP's around the world.
There's a social web which is giving us new kinds of content to deal with.
We have growing volumes.
We have a shortage of translators and those two things alone should mean higher prices, but they don't.
They mean lower prices.
The common sense advisor was just saying how weird it is that our industry has those two things shortage of resource is growing demand and prices that are constantly constantly dropping.
Something else I've seen since in the 25 years I've been in this industry, which obviously started at very young age, is shrinking deadlines.
As I've seen the different technology come online from the very first fax machines.
The very first modems I don't have any know.
Probably none of you Remember Remember permanent or ymodem with all every single technology technological feat have put more pressure on us for deadlines and.
That's continuing to this day, so it's quite funny to watch.
Over the years we also have new needs.
For example, we had just this week.
My translation company is doing 800,000 words in five days.
That's a new need.
Those those words had to be translated in that timeframe so that the company could understand and respond to a call for tenders.
So the market is completely changing and that is one of the reasons why we really need more and better language technology.

Something else that characterizes our world today in in the localization company side of things is the lack of visibility and we have, as a group have not been very good about making the world aware of translation.
Translation is totally not on the radar so you get these.
These, such as such as all this fantastic form, content that we've been talking about all this wonderful content and it's available only in English.
I'm not picking on Nokia because they actually captured the Indian market by translating their their interface into a dozen in these languages.
But the point is.
If people buy a cell phone in Estonia, I believe they have the right to support in Estonian and that is just not equitable right now.

The lion share content is in English, so why do we need language technology first of all, because there's a whole body of of content that is not at all being translated, which is the user support forums.
Customer support by the companies who sell in those countries.
There's another really, really imp.
Weren't inequality an?
It means the difference between life and death on a huge scale, and I'm not exaggerating because we had this study done just last month.
It came out by the Common sense advisory.
They did it for translators Without Borders was a study of the African translation industry.
And that study found that 97% of the respondents said that more translated information would help people protect their legal rights.
95% said that it would protect their human rights.
94% said it would protect.
Health, public health all across Africa, 91% said it would help contribute to the political process and democracy.
88% said it would help prevent ethnic conflict mean those are huge numbers and they're saying how important information is and how important translation is for that.

But for me, the most striking statistic of that whole study was the next one, that 63% of the respondents said that they knew somebody with somebody in their family or one of their friends who wouldn't ever died.
Who wouldn't have died if they had?
Sorry if they had access to translated information?
So this is really, really really important.
Even within the borders of Europe.
Your huge inequality's and what information is available to people.

And they gave us a good window on what content is available in languages, and you can see that English English is just literally off the page.
But when we start talking about what content, what information about health and.
Education and science and technology.
What information people have access to it drops off dramatically.
But even the most strongly represented European languages.

Even the most poorly represented European languages are still doing better than the languages of the developing world in terms of what content they have access to it.
We look at Latvian with 1.5 million speakers.
They still have twice as many pages as benggali, with 180 million speakers.
This is a really, really important issue and I think that.
We need a lot more language technology to deal with it better.

We've been working with machine translation since 2007.

So I think there's a lot of confusion in the market and the important takeaway I guess from this slide would be that that we believe in approach this engine agnostic.
So you see the engine to the process to the content and it's as simple as that and the other really important thing I want to say is quality.
I want to talk about empty quality.
This is an actual quote from one of our customers.
One of our earliest customers, we started doing French with them.
We moved to German Dutch.
Italian Spanish.
Chinese, Japanese.
So we just would take over 1 one more language, one more language, every project.
So they're not surprising.
Part of this is cost savings 30%.

Not surprising, but what I think is surprising to many people is.
And this is all a direct quote from one of our customers, he said, contrary to all expectations, using Mt has approved the translation quality.
I think that's really important.
I don't think we're shooting high enough with translation.
This automated translation I think we're shooting at Justine or understand ability, but we're not really shooting at high quality.
And yet if you do it.
Properly, if you train it properly, if you use controlled language, you can get fantastic results.
So in this in the client evaluation they said that we got 8.5, eight .25 out of 10 for empty.
The significant part of this is the next part of what he says.
He says their traditional TM's get 8 out of 10.
That's another dirty little secret I think.
Is that translation memories are always that good.
This particular client has hired us to clean up their translation memories.
They also said in the scoring was blind, so the reviewers didn't know that it was empty.

Otherwise they would have probably been a little tougher on it, but they thought it was just a normal human translation and they said that the 8 out of 10 on German, which is a tough language and empty, was nearly a 9 and it was the best translation.
Of course, where they never read so.

Selecting the right tool.
But it's a process that starts with authoring.
It goes through customization or training of the engine, piloting your process, processing the files, post editing, QA checks.
And the most probably the second most important part of this is feeding your corrections back into the engine and improving it in real time if you can.
So I'm just going to.
About one side of one part of this process, the very beginning part which is source content and we have a project with the European Union called, except where we're working on just that.

the University of Edinburgh University of Geneva and Lake Celera.

Because obviously form content is definitely Wild West, all sorts of silly mistakes at short forms, and so we need to get that a little bit better managed and so we have the success.
Project if anybody wants to join our special interest group.
If you have a company, if you have four content, if you have user generated content then you can join our special interest group and take our post editing platform and integrated into your forms OK.
This is the part of the Ted Talk where you give your wish list.
So OK, it's not a Ted talk, but I'm going to give you my wish list.

And going back and forth, and I think this should be all integrated in one place.

And.
I'm going to be even more beautiful, maybe controversial, with teams.
I think we should throw them out.
Big advantages that we've gotten from teams.

Empty is now the future team should be going into the empty engine and basta we shouldn't be going back and forth between teams and empty TM should be just another way to to build an empty engine, just as glossary's.
Just as technologies are.
So what I want to say is that information is important.
IT support companies.
It's a business right?
For people who buy software products.
That they be supported in their language, and it's a human right that people have access to the same information that we have because we speak English.
The access to the information they need.
To live healthy and productive lives.
And there is absolutely no way we're going to get to those two goals without better smarter language technology.
So thank you very much, thank you.
